body:
Problem:
1. Rightmost window retained vsep after adjacent window closed
2. Explicit width/height ignored due to win_equal() override
3. winfixwidth windows expanded when receiving space from closed windows

Solution:
1. Clear vsep_width for new lastwin in win_remove()
2. Add WSP_NOEQUAL flag to skip equalization when size explicitly set
3. Skip frame resizing for winfixwidth windows in winframe_remove()

Fix #32854

comment_data.body:
Looks like this doesn't fix the vsep issue if the window with the vsep isn't the last window:

```vim
botright vsplit
set winfixwidth
botright vsplit
botright split
wincmd p
quit
```

I think it's probably more appropriate to fixup the vsep somewhere like `winframe_remove` instead anyway? `win_remove` relates moreso to the window list.
range `FOR_ALL_WINDOWS_IN_TAB(fix_wp, target_tp)`  and find  if `frp->fr_parent == NULL` then reset  `vsep_width` ?

That'll work (though the `w_width` will be wrong), but it'll maybe be more efficient to check if the closed window was a rightmost window, and then recursively remove vseps of the windows to the left.

Might be a bit tricky; I'll see if I can come up with something.

Some frame must get the space here, otherwise it'll be possible for "gaps" in the frames.

```vim
set winfixwidth
vsplit
quit
mode
```

`winframe_find_altwin` already tries to respect `&winfixwidth/height`, but without any guarantee; maybe its logic can be improved somehow?

Like before, not as easy as skipping setting the width, otherwise the window will be the wrong width for the frame. (Look at the last column of the window and statusline after your change with the repro in the issue; it isn't rendered correctly)

I guess the only way is to check whether there's a `'winfixwidth'` window that would gain a vsep, and instead change the width of the frames. That could affect the sizes of other windows, though. May be a bit complicated... or maybe the logic in `win_split_ins` can be changed to improve this. I'll have a think... (later today) :thinking:
Okay, window expert :) It just occurred to me—if all other windows have wfw set, then who will receive the space?

> Okay, window expert :)

Lol, I wish; this stuff is super confusing to me :laughing:

> if all other windows have wfw set, then who will receive the space?

Generally space is stolen from a `'wfw'` window anyway.

Even without all the other changes in this PR, this change allows for zero-sized windows, which crashes Nvim. Pretty simple to trigger when not using `&wfw`.

I assume `do_equal` is usually set in these cases, so entirely ignoring it is probably wrong.

```lua
vim.cmd.vsplit()
vim.api.nvim_open_win(0, false, { win = -1, split = "right", width = 999 })
```
how do you feel the case for `winframe_restore` 🤔

this failed. after restore the width is changed

```
    it('winfixwidth preserved during window move operations #test', function()
      command('vsplit | vsplit | 2wincmd w')
      local left_win = api.nvim_get_current_win()
      api.nvim_win_set_width(left_win, 20)
      api.nvim_set_option_value('winfixwidth', true, { win = left_win })
      command('wincmd H')
      eq(20, api.nvim_win_get_width(left_win))
    end)
```

That doesn't call `winframe_restore` and fails on master and v0.9 (maybe other versions too). Don't think it's worth looking into here.

You need to trigger E36 from moving (not splitting) a window with some `'wfw'` windows nearby. Maybe run the test via gdb or add some logging to check you're hitting it. There's some "no room" tests in that file that you can copy and adjust to make that easier.

I can write one later if you're stuck, but it might be a while as today's looking busy. :smiling_face_with_tear:

maybe i can use `help` win for test 🤔

> I can write one later if you're stuck, but it might be a while as today's looking busy. 

no worry :)
perfect the resize case can be done in anther PR 🤔 ?

As you've already applied the change it can stay here, but it could do with a test where `'wfw'` doesn't cause the frame to resize if it's not the `altfr`, if that's possible. (Also a `winframe_restore` test as mentioned earlier)

comment_regular_data.body:
This is a Vim bug: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32854#issuecomment-3248545626
I'm not sure about this fix.

It might be a bit different — in nvim_open_win the window width is set directly, rather than resized🤔. I’m not completely sure about this. The fix for win_remove should also apply to Vim. I’ll try it out there.
Looks like the vsep bug didn't exist back in v9.0.0000; gonna bisect to see what introduced it (hopefully it wasn't me :innocent:)
Yup, matrix servers are [super duper offline](https://status.matrix.org/) at the moment :grin:
Okay after bisecting looks like it was indeed me that caused the vsep issue in https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/5866bc3a0f54115d5982fdc09bdbe4c45069265a :rocket:

Okay, seems this isn't actually a bug in my commit (phew :relieved:); the vsep issue reproduces in versions like v9.0.0000 (probably even earlier), but only if `&ea` is unset.

It just so happens that before that commit, the frame layout is slightly different such that `win_equal_req` calls `frame_new_width` on a leaf frame for the last window, which removes the vsep if `&ea` is set.

> Okay, seems this isn't actually a bug in my commit (phew 😌)

😊 that clears up my doubt. Since your commit didn’t change it, I was curious why it was that commit.
